titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: A beautiful day, comparatively mild & windless. I worked all day at the Charge for the Candidates, but I am too "hustled and bustled" to do good work, last of all work of that kind.
Was ever any really good work produced under conditions of haste? I doubt it
In the afternoon I walked round the Park with D
Cullagh: and then Lady Lawrence and George arrived.
Chesney sends me a photograph of himself in surplice, when a choir boy of S
Margaret's, Westminster. He is now a man of over forty, but his memories of S

Margaret's retain a strange hold over him. "The thoughts of a boy are long, long thoughts", – which is rather a terrifying reflection for their seniors, who may make a lasting impression which they do not suspect & would not at all approve. I remember "little Mac", as we called him, as a small & extremely pugnacious boy, who was always being reported for disorder!
